I think the hours posted are off - we went at 4 and 5 pm on a Thursday and it was closed, but it was open when we checked again at 6:30.  In short, it was worth wandering around for hours on La Rambla and Barri Gotic to try this place.  There are no menus, but there are only 4 different tapas offered and 3 different wines.  The wines are served in small drink glasses, and cost slightly more than 1 euro each.  There is a red wine, a white wine, and a rose - we tried the red and rose and were happy with both.  There are 4 choices in terms of food - a plate of salad (tomato, onion, olives with olive oil, 2 anchovies), a small plate of fried fish (looks exactly like Taiwanese style fried smelt, lightly battered and deep fried whole), a plate of bruschetta which looked like it had the tomato juice rubbed directly onto the bread, and a sausage on a small piece of toast.  The sausage didn't seem overly fatty and was well flavored.  The bruschetta was my least favorite, because I'm not such a big fan of bread, but I really enjoyed everything else - very simply fresh and delicious.  We had a great dinner here at a great price - 4 plates of fresh food and 2 cups of wine for a total of less than 12 euros for 2 people!  I fully recommend skipping the overpriced tourist trap places on La Rambla and walking over to this tiny hole in the wall place in the Barri Gotic.
